VLIB Function Reference

Histogram

Introduction and Use Cases

Histograms are used commonly as a discrete measure of the distribution of a given quantity.

Weighted histograms permit the user he flexibility to influence the relative importance of different values in the input data.

Specification

Function

Several functions are provided for histogram initialization and histogram computation, depending on input data size and other variants listed below.

Variants

This functionality is available in 2 variants, with 2 sub-variants of each. The 16-bit histograms also have a multi-dimensional variant:
  • 8-bit Histograms
    • 1D histogram
      • Globally weighted 1D histogram (VLIB_histogram_1D_U8)
      • Element-specifically weighted 1D histogram (VLIB_weightedHistogram_1D_U8)
  • 16-bit Histograms
    • 1D histogram
      • Globally weighted 1D histogram (VLIB_histogram_1D_U16)
      • Element-specifically weighted 1D histogram (VLIB_weightedHistogram_1D_U16)
    • nD histogram
      • Globally weighted nD histogram (VLIB_histogram_nD_U16)
      • Element-specifically weighted nD histogram (VLIB_weightedHistogram_nD_U16)

Notes

  • Please reference the specific APIs listed below for applicable notes and assumptions.

APIS

8-bit Histograms
  • VLIB_histogram_1D_Init_U8
  • VLIB_histogram_1D_U8
  • VLIB_weightedHistogram_1D_U8

16-bit Histograms

  • VLIB_histogram_1D_Init_U16
  • VLIB_histogram_1D_U16
  • VLIB_weightedHistogram_1D_U16
  • VLIB_histogram_nD_U16
  • VLIB_weightedHistogram_nD_U16
